Directions: Read this passage and answer each question that follows.
Title: The Farm
Author: by Laurie O. Curtis
Content: with black shutters, willow trees and lilacs
I'm the scratchy screen doors that catch the stitch in your sweater
and the worn blue jean jacket smelling of silage¹
and hanging on hooks on the back porch
I'm the warm green water in the pond
and tiny clumps of algae cling to fingers
I'm the knot on the string
and the wooden ladder to the hayloft
I'm the musty burlap² feed bag
I'm the heavy black milking straps
I'm the barn cats crowded around
with heads cocked for a quick squirt of milk
and the fly strips hanging in the barn
and the fly strips hanging in the barn
and the wagon, sides swollen and swaying,
stacked to the top with hay
Copyright: Excerpt from “The Farm,” by Laurie O. Curtis, from Cricket Magazine, September 2011, Vol. 39, No. 1. Copyright © 2011 by Carus Publishing Company. Used by permission of Cricket Media via Copyright Clearance Center.
References: silage - grass or dried hay stored in airtight conditions
